summary: Rigorous economic research shows that high-deductible health plans reduce total spendingâ€”but primarily by reducing both necessary and unnecessary care, without improving patient price shopping. Despite this, HDHPs have been widely adopted across the U.S., highlighting a disconnect between design and outcomes.
solutions: Value-Based Insurance Design (VBID) to lower cost-sharing for essential services.
Patient education to improve understanding of covered preventive care.
Price transparency tools to encourage better consumer decision-making.
Employer plan design changes to exempt chronic disease management from deductibles.

articles.title: What Does a Deductible Do?: The Impact of Cost-Sharing on Health Care Prices, Quantities, and Spending Dynamics
articles.summary: A major employer's shift to a high-deductible plan cut spending by 13%, but patients reduced both high- and low-value care and showed no evidence of learning to price shop even after two years.
articles.authors: Zarek Brot-Goldberg, Amitabh Chandra, Benjamin Handel, Jonathan Kolstad
